author: Martha
title: Not Everything Called "Tea" Is Actually Tea – And That’s Fine!
content:
When we talk about “tea,” we’re often referring to a wide world of warm, comforting drinks that go far beyond the classic tea plant, Camellia sinensis. Technically speaking, only beverages made from this plant—such as black, green, white, oolong, and pu-erh tea—are considered true tea. But in everyday language, we use the term far more openly. And honestly? That’s part of the charm.

Herbal blends like chamomile, rooibos, peppermint, or even creative infusions with spices and dried fruits may not be “tea” in the strict botanical sense, but they carry the same spirit: the comfort of a warm cup, the ritual of preparation, and the joy of slowing down for a moment of calm.

This blog follows that wider, more generous definition.

It’s not a scientific journal. I won’t be measuring oxidation levels or comparing caffeine content in minute detail. Instead, I want to focus on the joy of tea. The curiosity it sparks. The way different cultures have developed their own traditions around a simple cup. And the quiet, everyday luxury of enjoying something made with care.

One of the most delightful things you can do is step into a well-curated tea shop. Shelves lined with tins from around the world, the warm scent of dried herbs and leaves in the air, and a person behind the counter who knows just what to recommend for your mood or your taste—there’s something deeply rewarding about that. It turns tea into a little daily adventure.

There’s a flavor for almost everyone in the world of tea. Something floral, something earthy, something spicy, bitter, sweet, fruity, or grassy. You might not like everything—but chances are, there’s something you’ll love, if you’re open to the journey.

So think of this blog as an invitation. Not to become a tea expert, but to start a culinary discovery—one cup at a time.

author: Martha
title: A Cup of Calm: How Tea Can Help You Reset After a Busy Day
content:
In a world that moves fast—emails, notifications, deadlines, never-ending to-do lists—it’s easy to get swept along without pause. But sometimes, all it takes is a cup of tea to gently put the brakes on and reconnect with yourself.

There’s something grounding about brewing tea with intention. Boiling the water, choosing the leaves, waiting as it steeps, watching the color slowly deepen in the cup. It doesn’t demand much, but it offers a moment—a space between everything else that’s going on.

For many people, this small ritual becomes a quiet transition. A way to shift gears after work, to mark the end of one part of the day and the beginning of something softer, slower, more present. It doesn’t have to be fancy. Just five minutes with your hands around a warm mug, letting your thoughts settle and your breath deepen, can make a noticeable difference.

It’s about more than just hydration or flavor—it’s about creating space. A kind of gentle, daily mindfulness. No apps, no pressure, just steam rising from a cup and a brief permission to do nothing else but enjoy it.

Maybe it becomes a habit: the “after work” tea, the “before bed” blend, the weekend pot you brew just because. These little moments can be anchors, subtle reminders that you don’t always have to rush.

So if life feels a bit too fast, try slowing down with a cup of tea. Not as a cure-all, but as a simple act of care—for your body, your mind, and your sense of balance.

title: Lapacho: The Tree Bark Tea with a Gentle Soul
author: Martha
content:
Lapacho isn’t your typical tea. In fact, it’s not made from leaves at all, but from the inner bark of the Pau d'Arco tree, native to South America. For generations, families across countries like Brazil, Argentina, and Paraguay have brewed it not just as a drink, but as a trusted home remedy.

The flavor of Lapacho is mild and slightly sweet, with gentle cinnamon-like notes and a smooth, woody warmth. It’s caffeine-free, which makes it a calming choice at any time of day—and especially nice in the evening, when you want something comforting but not stimulating.

Traditionally, Lapacho is simmered rather than steeped. The bark needs a bit more time in hot water to release its subtle character. It’s not flashy or bold, but it grows on you. The kind of tea you reach for when you want something earthy, grounding, and just a little different from your usual herbal rotation.

What makes Lapacho particularly fascinating is how deeply it’s woven into everyday life in parts of South America. It’s often shared during moments of quiet conversation, or served with meals as a gentle digestive. Some families pass down their own little “recipes” for blending it with spices or citrus peels to create their favorite version.

For those used to green teas or fruit infusions, Lapacho offers a new path—a taste that feels ancient, almost forgotten, yet wonderfully familiar once you try it.

If you ever come across it in a tea shop, give it a try. Let it simmer, take your time, and enjoy the feeling of sipping something that’s traveled a long way—across forests, families, and time—to end up in your cup.

title: Mate Tea: A Gentle Wake-Up Call from South America
author: Martha
content:
Mate tea—known simply as mate—is more than just a drink. In countries like Argentina, Uruguay, and Paraguay, it’s a daily ritual, a cultural touchstone, and a shared experience. But outside of South America, many first encounter mate in a completely different form: sweetened, bottled, and ice-cold—often grabbed from a convenience store fridge.

And while that version has its place, the traditional way of preparing mate tells a very different story.

Properly brewed mate is warm, earthy, and far gentler than its bottled counterpart might suggest. The trick is in the temperature: never use boiling water. Around 70°C (160–175°F) is ideal. This brings out the smooth, grassy flavors without turning it overly bitter. When done right, mate is energizing but not jittery—more of a steady lift than a caffeine spike.

The tea is made from dried leaves of the yerba mate plant, which is rich in natural stimulants and antioxidants. But what makes mate special isn't just its chemistry—it’s the way it’s enjoyed. Traditionally served in a hollowed-out gourd with a metal straw called a bombilla, mate is often passed from person to person in a shared moment of connection.

Of course, you don’t need a gourd or bombilla to enjoy it. A French press, tea strainer, or even a simple teapot will do. What matters is the attention you bring to it—taking the time to brew it with care, sip slowly, and maybe let it replace that second (or third) coffee.

If you're curious about alternatives to espresso or energy drinks, mate might surprise you. It’s bold yet balanced, with a kind of calm focus that fits well into everything from morning routines to late-night coding sessions.

So next time you’re looking for something with a little kick, consider giving traditional mate a chance. It’s a taste that lingers—in the best way.

title: Guayusa vs. Mate: Two Energizing Teas, One Calmer Kick
author: Martha
content:
At first glance, guayusa and yerba mate seem like close cousins—and in many ways, they are. Both are traditional South American brews made from the dried leaves of rainforest trees. Both contain caffeine. Both are known for providing a clean, focused kind of energy. But look a little closer, and you’ll find some subtle—and intriguing—differences.

Let’s start with taste.

Mate has a bold, grassy, and slightly bitter flavor that can take a little getting used to—especially if brewed strong or with very hot water. It’s often described as earthy or smoky if it is toasted after the harvest.

Guayusa, on the other hand, is noticeably smoother. The taste is rounder, softer, almost naturally sweet, with a gentle herbal note. It lacks the bitterness of mate, making it an easier entry point for newcomers to South American teas. Some even say it reminds them of green tea, but with a bit more body.

Now for the effects.

Both drinks contain caffeine, but the experience is different. Mate gives a steady lift—alert but grounded. Guayusa feels a bit more like a mental clarity boost. Some people describe it as having the focus of green tea with the clean energy of coffee, but without the crash.

Interestingly, guayusa also contains theobromine—the same gentle stimulant found in dark chocolate—along with L-theanine, which is known for its calming properties. The result? A kind of awake-and-centered feeling that’s great for long, focused tasks.

And then there’s the ritual.

While mate is deeply embedded in South American culture with traditional preparation tools like the gourd and bombilla, guayusa is often brewed more casually—like a regular loose-leaf tea. It's easier to integrate into modern routines, especially if you're brewing on the go.

So which one should you try?

If you’re into bold flavors and enjoy tradition, mate has a lot to offer. If you’re looking for something smoother, more mellow, and easy to drink, guayusa might become your new go-to.

In the end, both are worth discovering. Think of them not as rivals, but as two different paths to the same goal: feeling good, energized, and just a little more in tune with yourself.

title: A World of Green Tea: Beyond the Well Known Black Teabag
author: Martha
content:
In Germany, when people think of "real tea," it’s often black tea that comes to mind—maybe a classic Darjeeling or a strong black tea, like it is served in East Frisia with heavy cream and with a piece of 'Kluntje'—a large, glistening, amber coloured sugar crystal that cracks under the heat of the tea and dissolves slowly.

Green tea, if it's mentioned at all, is sometimes written off as bitter or bland. But that usually says more about the brewing method than the tea itself.

Because once you step into the world of green tea, you discover something truly eye-opening: an incredible variety of flavors, textures, and traditions. All from the very same plant—Camellia sinensis—but treated in completely different ways.

Let’s take a quick tour.

In Japan, green tea is steamed after harvesting, which locks in its vibrant green color and brings out fresh, grassy, almost oceanic flavors. Teas like Sencha, Gyokuro, and Bancha each have their own personality—from delicate and sweet to more robust and earthy.

Over in China, green teas are usually pan-fired, giving them a nuttier, warmer profile. Think of Longjing (Dragon Well), with its signature chestnut note, or Biluochun, which is floral, light, and incredibly fragrant.

Vietnam and South Korea also produce beautiful green teas—often lesser-known, but with their own regional character. Some are bold and vegetal, others are smooth and slightly fruity. And the quality? Often excellent, especially if you’re willing to explore beyond the supermarket shelf.

But here’s the thing: green tea needs a little love.

It’s not a “pour boiling water and forget it” kind of drink. Use water that’s too hot, and even the finest Bancha will turn harsh, astringent, even downright unpleasant. Unfortunately many manufacturers of supermarket tea print on their packages the advice to alsways use boiling water. But this is meant for hygienic reason and has nothing to to with taste.  But please, treat green tea gently—let your water cool to around 70–80°C first, steep it for just the right amount of time—and suddenly, you’re tasting subtle notes you never knew existed. And often it is more tasty not to let it steep for whole three minutes as written on the package! Sweetness, umami, floral undertones, even buttery smoothness.

And here’s another secret: good green tea doesn’t stop at just one cup.

If you buy a high-quality green tea, a single teaspoon of leaves can yield multiple infusions—each one slightly different from the last. The first steep might be light and fragrant, the second deeper and rounder, the third more mellow and mineral. It’s like watching the personality of the tea unfold, layer by layer.

Try it out, take your time, and notice how each cup tells a slightly different story. That, too, is part of the magic.

Once you get a feel for it, green tea becomes more than just a beverage. It’s a quiet craft. A daily moment of intention. And above all, a reminder that even the simplest things can surprise you—when you approach them with patience and curiosity.

So if your only experience with green tea came from a dusty teabag and a boiling kettle, maybe it’s time to give it another chance. There’s a whole world in that cup—waiting to be discovered.

title: One Plant, Many Faces: White, Green, and Black Tea
author: Martha
content:
It might come as a surprise, but white, green, and black tea all come from the same plant—Camellia sinensis. What makes them different isn't the origin, but the way the leaves are handled after harvest. It's a story of timing, technique, and transformation.

Let’s break it down.

White tea is the most delicate. It's made from young tea buds and leaves that are simply picked and dried—sometimes in the sun, sometimes with a bit of gentle heat. There's almost no processing, which means the tea stays light, floral, and naturally sweet. It’s subtle and quiet, with a softness that invites slow sipping.

Green tea, on the other hand, is a little more hands-on. The leaves are quickly heated—either by steaming (as in Japan) or pan-firing (as in China)—to stop the natural oxidation process. This keeps the tea green, both in color and flavor. The result? A vibrant range of tastes, from grassy and fresh to nutty and savory, depending on the style and origin.

Black tea goes further. Here, the leaves are intentionally oxidized—a natural chemical reaction that darkens the leaf and deepens the flavor. The result is bold, malty, often a bit astringent, with notes that can range from dried fruit to honey to spice. It’s the most familiar tea to many people in the West, especially in blends like Earl Grey or English Breakfast.

The fascinating part? These three types can come from exactly the same garden, even the same row of tea bushes. What changes is the craftsmanship.

And here’s where it gets interesting for the drinker: each style speaks to a different mood, a different moment.

White tea is gentle and meditative. Green tea is crisp, refreshing, and nuanced. Black tea is strong, comforting, and full-bodied. None is better than the other—it’s more like asking whether you’re in the mood for a quiet whisper, a clear conversation, or a warm, deep voice. If it is snowy outside, an intense black tea may warm your heart. And if the sun is burning on a long summer day, a hot green tee can bring a surprising freshness, you never expected unless you try it out!

So next time you're standing in front of the tea shelf, wondering what to try, remember: they all begin the same way. What changes is the journey the leaves have taken—and the kind of experience you're ready to welcome into your cup.

title: Flavouring Tea the Natural Way: Jasmine, Bergamot, and Beyond
author: Martha
content:
While there’s something undeniably comforting about a simple cup of pure tea—whether it’s green, black, or white—there’s also a world of exciting flavors waiting to be explored. And the best part? You don’t need artificial flavorings to enhance the experience. Nature has plenty to offer when it comes to giving tea a fragrant, flavorful twist.

One of the most beloved additions is jasmine. The soft, floral scent of jasmine blossoms has been paired with tea for centuries, particularly in Chinese green teas. The delicate perfume infuses the leaves naturally, creating a subtle, sweet aroma that lingers with every sip. Jasmine tea is perfect when you need something calming, a bit exotic, yet familiar.

Then there’s bergamot, the citrus fruit that transforms Earl Grey into something special. The zesty, slightly bitter notes of bergamot add a layer of complexity to the tea, creating a perfect balance between fresh and bold. It’s the ideal companion for a quiet afternoon, when you want something light yet full of character.

And let’s not forget, Earl Grey isn’t just for relaxing afternoons—it’s also a perfect choice for those moments when you want to drift away in thought, much like Captain Picard of the Enterprise, who couldn’t go a day without his beloved cup of Earl Grey. For those who wish to escape the hustle and bustle of daily life and dream of the stars, Earl Grey might just be the perfect invitation to leave the world behind, even if only for a brief, quiet moment.

But the world of natural flavoring doesn’t stop there. Citrus peels—from oranges to lemons to limes—are another lovely addition to tea. They brighten up the cup with a lively, tangy note that’s perfect for a morning brew or an afternoon pick-me-up. And if you’re feeling adventurous, try adding a little spice. Cinnamon sticks, cloves, ginger, or cardamom can turn a simple black tea into a fragrant, warming delight. It’s like inviting the cozy embrace of winter into your teacup, no matter the season.

The beauty of these natural flavors is that they’re never overpowering. They complement, rather than mask, the tea itself. Whether it’s a handful of dried rose petals, a few bits of dried apple, or a sprinkle of lavender, these additions enhance the tea’s natural qualities, offering a layered, nuanced experience.

So next time you’re looking for a new twist on your tea routine, consider reaching for something flavored with nature’s gifts. Whether it’s a handful of dried herbs or a burst of citrus, you’ll be surprised by how the right ingredients can elevate the entire experience.
